articles.headline: Head of German Central Bank Is Stepping Down
articles.snippet: Axel A. Weber had been considered a front-runner to succeed Jean-Claude Trichet as president of the European Central Bank later this year.
articles.abstract: Axel A. Weber had been considered a front-runner to succeed Jean-Claude Trichet as president of the European Central Bank later this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  Axel Weber took himself out of the running Friday to become president of the European Central Bank, leaving deep uncertainty about who else can handle a job that is crucial to the survival of the euro.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: A Brittle Leader, Appearing Strong
articles.snippet: The end came suddenly for Hosni Mubarak, who consistently rejected bold action in favor of caution.
articles.abstract: The end came suddenly for Hosni Mubarak, who consistently rejected bold action in favor of caution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hosni Mubarak’s legacy was supposed to be stability. During almost three decades in power, he rejected bold action in favor of caution. He took half-steps at economic liberalization, preserved the peace with Israel, gave his police force the power to arrest without charge and allowed only the veneer of democracy to take hold.

articles.headline: When Love Outgrows Gifts on Valentine’s Day
articles.snippet: Long-term relationships do not survive without gifts. But they are not the gifts you may think.
articles.abstract: Long-term relationships do not survive without gifts. But they are not the gifts you may think.
articles.lead_paragraph: As if we needed another sign that Valentine’s Day is getting awfully expensive, the coupon Web sites have now gotten into the game.

articles.headline: U.S. Approves Corn Modified for Ethanol
articles.snippet: A type of corn that is genetically engineered to make it easier to convert into ethanol was approved for commercial growing by the Department of Agriculture.
articles.abstract: A type of corn that is genetically engineered to make it easier to convert into ethanol was approved for commercial growing by the Department of Agriculture.
articles.lead_paragraph: A type of corn that is genetically engineered to make it easier to convert into ethanol was approved for commercial growing by the Department of Agriculture.

articles.headline: From Pentagon, a Buy Rating on Contractors
articles.snippet: Defense Department officials have been making the rounds of investment gatherings, and they’re bullish on military contractors. They have to be.
articles.abstract: Defense Department officials have been making the rounds of investment gatherings, and they’re bullish on military contractors. They have to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Cowen & Company military industry investment conference on Wednesday, the breakfast speaker was a man named Ashton B. Carter. A former academic and industry consultant, Dr. Carter, as he likes to call himself  he has a doctorate in theoretical physics, in case you were wondering  is the Defense Department’s under secretary for acquisitions, technology and logistics. That is, he’s the Pentagon’s chief weapons buyer.

articles.headline: Uncharted Ground After End of Egypt’s Regime
articles.snippet: Egypt will face the meaning of its revolution, posing challenges as myriad as President Mubarak’s departure was singular.
articles.abstract: Egypt will face the meaning of its revolution, posing challenges as myriad as President Mubarak’s departure was singular.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  One revolution ended Friday. Another may soon begin.

articles.headline: Military Offers Assurances to Egypt and Neighbors
articles.snippet: As a new era dawned in Egypt, its leaders sought to project control and assuage fears about military rule.
articles.abstract: As a new era dawned in Egypt, its leaders sought to project control and assuage fears about military rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  As a new era dawned in Egypt on Saturday, the army leadership sought to reassure Egyptians and the world that it would shepherd a transition to civilian rule and honor international commitments like the peace treaty with Israel.

articles.headline: Imagining Life Without Fannie and Freddie
articles.snippet: An Obama administration report zeroed in on what’s wrong in the mortgage system. But there will be a brawl over the report’s ideas on how to fix it.
articles.abstract: An Obama administration report zeroed in on what’s wrong in the mortgage system. But there will be a brawl over the report’s ideas on how to fix it.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUDOS to Treasury and the Department of Housing and Urban Development for some straight talk about the nation’s broken mortgage system.

articles.headline: The Dirty Little Secrets of Search
articles.snippet: How a campaign of paid links on all kinds of unrelated Web sites pushed one retailer to the top of Google results.
articles.abstract: How a campaign of paid links on all kinds of unrelated Web sites pushed one retailer to the top of Google results.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRETEND for a moment that you are Google’s search engine.

articles.headline: Emirates’ Ambitions Worry European Rivals
articles.snippet: Given the growth of Dubai’s fast-growing flagship airline, and its central location, airlines like Air France and Lufthansa are nervous.
articles.abstract: Given the growth of Dubai’s fast-growing flagship airline, and its central location, airlines like Air France and Lufthansa are nervous.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates

articles.headline: In U.S. Signals to Egypt, Obama Straddled a Rift
articles.snippet: President Obama had to navigate between the counsel of foreign policy traditionalists and a younger White House.
articles.abstract: President Obama had to navigate between the counsel of foreign policy traditionalists and a younger White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Helene Cooper, Mark Landler and David E. Sanger.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Obama’s Budget Seeks Deep Cuts in Domestic Spending
articles.snippet: President Obama, who is proposing his third annual budget on Monday, will say that it can reduce projected deficits by $1.1 trillion over the next decade, according to a senior official.
articles.abstract: President Obama, who is proposing his third annual budget on Monday, will say that it can reduce projected deficits by $1.1 trillion over the next decade, according to a senior official.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama, who is proposing his third annual budget on Monday, will say that it can reduce projected deficits by $1.1 trillion over the next decade, enough to stabilize the nation’s fiscal health and buy time to address its longer-term problems, according to a senior administration official.

articles.headline: For Some Troops, Powerful Drug Cocktails Have Deadly Results
articles.snippet: In trying to treat the physical and psychological effects of war, doctors are prescribing medications that can have fatal interactions.
articles.abstract: In trying to treat the physical and psychological effects of war, doctors are prescribing medications that can have fatal interactions.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by James Dao, Benedict Carey and Dan Frosch and written by Mr. Dao.
articles.byline: By James Dao, Benedict Carey and Dan Frosch

articles.headline: Egypt’s Path After Uprising Does Not Have to Follow Iran’s
articles.snippet: There is a fear in the West, one rarely echoed in Egypt, that the revolution could mimic Iran’s, when radical Islamists ultimately led a movement that began with a broad base. But the two nations are very different.
articles.abstract: There is a fear in the West, one rarely echoed in Egypt, that the revolution could mimic Iran’s, when radical Islamists ultimately led a movement that began with a broad base. But the two nations are very different.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Two Egyptian leaders have been struck down in 30 years: one by an Islamist assassin’s bullets, the other by the demands of hundreds of thousands of protesters in a peaceful uprising. The first event, the death of President Anwar el-Sadat, marked a spectacle of the most militant brand of political Islam. The revolution the world witnessed Friday, the toppling of President Hosni Mubarak, may herald the dawn of something else.

articles.headline: No Argument: Thomas Keeps 5-Year Silence
articles.snippet: Next Tuesday will mark five years since Justice Clarence Thomas has spoken during a court argument.
articles.abstract: Next Tuesday will mark five years since Justice Clarence Thomas has spoken during a court argument.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The anniversary will probably be observed in silence.

articles.headline: Egyptian Military Dissolves Parliament
articles.snippet: The military, complying with most of the opposition’s principal demands, said that it had dissolved the parliament, suspended its constitution and called for elections in six months.
articles.abstract: The military, complying with most of the opposition’s principal demands, said that it had dissolved the parliament, suspended its constitution and called for elections in six months.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  The Egyptian military consolidated its control on Sunday over what it has called a democratic transition from nearly three decades of President Hosni Mubarak’s authoritarian rule, dissolving the feeble Parliament, suspending the Constitution and calling for elections in six months in sweeping steps that echoed protesters’ demands.

articles.headline: Housing Market Looks Sickest in Cities That Once Seemed Immune
articles.snippet: As Florida and the Southwest have begun to stabilize, the pain has moved to economically diverse cities where the boom was relatively restrained, like Seattle, Atlanta and Minneapolis.
articles.abstract: As Florida and the Southwest have begun to stabilize, the pain has moved to economically diverse cities where the boom was relatively restrained, like Seattle, Atlanta and Minneapolis.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  Few believed the housing market here would ever collapse. Now they wonder if it will ever stop slumping.

articles.headline: At Media Companies, a Nation of Serfs
articles.snippet: Facebook, Twitter and The Huffington Post have done well for themselves using unpaid contributors. It’s enough to make a professional writer nervous.
articles.abstract: Facebook, Twitter and The Huffington Post have done well for themselves using unpaid contributors. It’s enough to make a professional writer nervous.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the fizz, if not a great big bubble, seems to have returned to media, depending on how you define “media.”

articles.headline: Uneven Rise for Groupon in Japan
articles.snippet: Groupon has grown rapidly in Japan, but its growth has not come without missteps, or rivals.
articles.abstract: Groupon has grown rapidly in Japan, but its growth has not come without missteps, or rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: NIIGATA, Japan  In this blustery provincial city on Honshu’s northwest coast, dotted with rice paddies and pachinko parlors, a popular new service has people buzzing: Groupon.

articles.headline: In Digital Era, Music Spotters Feed a Machine
articles.snippet: Start-ups that help users discover music have created new kinds of jobs.
articles.abstract: Start-ups that help users discover music have created new kinds of jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Sure, Shazam, the popular music-spotting cellphone application, can identify that Rihanna track. But what about the new song from the Sandwitches, a Bay Area folk-rock band?

articles.headline: Word and Lyric, Giffords Labors to Speak Again
articles.snippet: From mouthing words to speaking, Representative Gabrielle Giffords is on the slow road to recovery.
articles.abstract: From mouthing words to speaking, Representative Gabrielle Giffords is on the slow road to recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  Representative Gabrielle Giffords, an eloquent speaker before she was shot in the head last month, is relearning the skill  progressing from mouthing words and lip-syncing songs to talking briefly by telephone to her brother-in-law in space.
articles.byline: By Marc Lacey and James C. McKinley Jr

articles.headline: China Replaced Japan in 2010 as No. 2 Economy
articles.snippet: Japan’s economy has been surpassed by China’s after it shrank slightly in the last quarter of 2010.
articles.abstract: Japan’s economy has been surpassed by China’s after it shrank slightly in the last quarter of 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan’s economy contracted in the fourth quarter when compared with the previous three months, though analysts are optimistic about the country’s prospects for the rest of the year.

articles.headline: A Tunisian-Egyptian Link That Shook Arab History
articles.snippet: A two-year collaboration gave birth to a pan-Arab democracy movement that mixed the tactics of nonviolent resistance with Silicon Valley marketing.
articles.abstract: A two-year collaboration gave birth to a pan-Arab democracy movement that mixed the tactics of nonviolent resistance with Silicon Valley marketing.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As protesters in Tahrir Square faced off against pro-government forces, they drew a lesson from their counterparts in Tunisia: “Advice to the youth of Egypt: Put vinegar or onion under your scarf for tear gas.”
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: States Aim Ax at Health Cost of Retirement
articles.snippet: Searing rises in health costs have reopened the pledges made to local government workers, past and present.
articles.abstract: Searing rises in health costs have reopened the pledges made to local government workers, past and present.
articles.lead_paragraph: Governors and mayors facing large deficits have set their sights on a relatively new target  the soaring expense of health benefits for millions of retired state and local workers.

articles.headline: Netbooks Lose Status as Tablets Like the iPad Rise
articles.snippet: Swept aside by the laptop and the iPad, the netbook is no longer a contender. But the small notebook computers continue to do brisk business in China and Latin America.
articles.abstract: Swept aside by the laptop and the iPad, the netbook is no longer a contender. But the small notebook computers continue to do brisk business in China and Latin America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Remember the Last Big Thing in computing? You’ll be forgiven for having forgotten it was the netbook  a small notebook computer with a slender price tag, about $300.

articles.headline: Egypt Army Sets 6-Month Blueprint, but Future Role Is Unclear
articles.snippet: The Egyptian military moved to clear the last protesters from Tahrir Square on Monday, news reports said, as the armed forces consolidated their control over what it has called a democratic transition.
articles.abstract: The Egyptian military moved to clear the last protesters from Tahrir Square on Monday, news reports said, as the armed forces consolidated their control over what it has called a democratic transition.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  The military officers who have governed Egypt since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak on Friday have laid out a brisk six-month timetable in which to draft constitutional amendments, submit them to a referendum and elect a new government, stirring debate about the military’s long-term intentions.

articles.headline: Obama’s Budget Focuses on Path to Rein In Deficit
articles.snippet: President Obama’s proposal and a coming House vote on G.O.P. spending cuts show the parties’ competing visions.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s proposal and a coming House vote on G.O.P. spending cuts show the parties’ competing visions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With President Obama’s release on Monday of a budget for next year and House action this week on a Republican plan for immediate deep spending cuts, the nation is getting its clearest view since the president took office of the parties’ competing visions of the role of government, the urgency of addressing the deficit and the best path to long-term economic success.

articles.headline: Iran Uses Force Against Protests as Region Erupts
articles.snippet: Hundreds of riot police officers deployed in key locations to thwart a march in solidarity with Egypt.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of riot police officers deployed in key locations to thwart a march in solidarity with Egypt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of riot police officers in Iran beat protesters and fired tear gas Monday to contain the most significant street protests since the end of the 2009 uprising there, as security forces around the region moved — sometimes brutally — to prevent new unrest in sympathy with the opposition victory in Egypt.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Alan Cowell
